message: but the single day event, more frequently might be more realistic --- interested to hear what others think definitely
unfortunately, we did a horrible job of getting the word out and were the only ones who actually participated --- took place at the Code Factory
Already expressed my interest. Why not a single day event once a quarter. I usually need a day to recover.

we were thinking of organizing one again, only having it at Mercury Grove (need to double-check with Scott, but he seemed warm to the idea); and having it a bit more structured; but the idea still being about comraderie and building a prototype version of a product idea
A couple years ago, Brierwood organized a little weekend hackathon; similar to the one day HackOtt thing, except over the course of a weekend, and less about the competition aspect

its really about how much can be realistically accomplished --- the weekend idea is much more difficult to manage in terms of finding time, but a lot more can be done; there would be a long leadup and give people plenty of time to get ready
And since I'm only in Ottawa on weekends, I'd be up for a Saturday event! (Two days would be too much for me, need to spend at least some of the weekend visiting with my wife)
I've found single day, two-person team, hackathons to be the right mix. As long as you don't try to make a pretty looking product, it's not too hard to make something functional in a day
RoR baby

I'm all in for this! I have to say I'm with @JonA, single day 2 hacker is a good mix. I also think that type of event could have a little something special in terms of presence on the web like, ( top of my head ) a bot that would post on twitter every time a team commits on github for the hackaton or something along those lines. In the end, I like the idea and I'm willing to participate!
@phi1rene I love "live walls" of any type.

@jevy yeah me too, I've always wondered if it could make a good idea ( maybe it already exists ), something like a plugin based web app that receives msg from facebook, twitter, whatever else through that plugin interface and then post them on a live wall... maybe it would be a good idea for a hackathon...
@phi1rene something like CIA https://www.ohloh.net/p/cia ?
Oh my bad, it looks like CIA is offline http://scanlime.org/2011/05/cia-vc-service-is-down-indefinitely/
The code is still around though
The update on that same blog post looks like it will be back!
@allanfalloon yeah, I think you nailed it. Although, from the arch map it looks overkill for just a "updates live wall" I don't know. Definitively, worth a look. Thanks
sorry @alanfalloon, I'm about to suggest to the dev team of convore to add autocomplete for usernames
BTW, @phi1rene I have done a fair amount of git hook hacking, if you want any help with that end of it... :)

@phi1rene I think you could whip up something in pretty short order, especially if you limit yourself to git and only one display method (twitter or web updates). I think the git hooks in CIA might be a good starting point though.

@alanfalloon, thanks... That's great.. I'm gonna look into this over the week-end, gotta a few projects to end before starting on new stuff. I may take this opportunity to start on python/django or get back in RoR. First gonna have to settle on what I want this to do. I've also seen those: http://help.github.com/post-receive-hooks/ which would post on twitter for you automatically... So there's may be no need for such projects/tool.
weekend hackathon would be fun(also, the django-dash is coming up soon I think)
I'm with @phi1rene and @JonA on a single day event.
It's also a smaller time commitment, so that should hopefully result in a bigger turnout
So it seems people are interested.
Would it be theme based of some sort?  Catering to a particular domain?  Using particular APIs (that's been done!)?  Free-for all?
Shawn had some ideas there; but I cannot recall the details
we wanted to create some sort of theme, while leaving it very open --- basically a theme meant to inspire rather than restrict
eg. the theme is "green" or "freedom" :)

I saw Ed tonight and of course, he offered up Shopify --- but I think Mercury Grove has a different atmosphere which would be nice to try out; as long as the internet actually functions to some degree
going with the idea Phil had earlier for a live wall, maybe the theme could be "visualization"?
right. Shopify is awesome but moving around might bring awareness to other companies. the internet would have to be working better for sure.

yeah; I like the idea of theme --- I just don't want to restrict it too much; i.e. I want it to be something that can be easily fit into pretty much every topic; my thought (and others can disagree) is that this would be an opportunity to perhaps get an initial version of an idea/product that you've been thinking about for a while, but could never execute on due to time constraints
"visualization" could fit that bill if its framed properly

@rvanmelle, @jevy I could see themes like "automation" or "every day tool" or "third-party widget" ( I'm not sure of the name here, but those widget you can install on a page and they dl code and run it on your page like the twitter widget for ex )...
More potential themes: dealing with data ("big data", natural language processing, basic data mining)
I would be interested in a project using Python's NLTK (Natural Language Toolkit)
I'd love to learn when the apps present some of the framework stuff they really leverage, I want to learn more from the Django world (speaking as a Rails guy)
Would it be possible to have some friendly Rails vs Django comp?

I'm actually getting into Django these days (never been much of a web guy).  I really like Python, so that justifies my choice.  As I get more up to speed, I'd be interested in learning about the Rails way of doing things.

all input has been processed and we will eventually move on this :)  as for Rails vs Django --- I've done both; I think Rails will win over a short period of time; but Django will rule over a longer time frame

@jevy Django has in my opinion has easier to understand form validation and each application is separate. Where as Rails has better TDD, migrations, scaffold/generators, coffeescript and jquery support built in. Also Rails has full scripting in their templates although it can be debated as to whether this is a better feature. Also I'd mention that each one has plugins/apps to add features the other has.
